ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a tremendous amount about the discipline of art history and the cultures and histories of the various peoples who engaged with the Silk Roads.
I learn an incredible amount about the Silk Roads and the various civilizations and art.
I get a very comprehensive view of the Silk Road from the art historical perspective.
I learned about the Silk Road(s) and the various civilizations that lived in the area, as well as the art forms they created.
I learned about the arts of the Silk Roads region.
Overview of arts along the Silk Road and how they fit into the context of where they were found, how to analyze art in mostly objects (vases, plates, statues).
I learned about the art world (e.g., material culture, common motifs, religious art, etc) and historical context of the Silk Roads, spanning many eras, cultures, and geographical regions.

I learned about the different peoples, places, and objects of the regions relevant to the Silk Roads (roughly, 2000BC to 500AD). I learned about various nations and peoples (Parthians, Kushans, Yuezhi, Sogdians, etc.) and studied objects from these cultures. Visual analysis and pattern recognition, including the vocabulary necessary to describe objects, were some important skills I developed during close observation of objects during lectures and for the brief notes/final project. Moreover, I got an opportunity to engage with these objects in a creative way through the flexible format of the final project.

I learned about the major themes, motifs' meanings, and cultures in art histories of various civilizations along the Silk Road over the time period from the Bronze Age to Sogdians. This includes Ancient China, steppe nomads, Ancient Romans, Ancient Greeks, Ancient Persian, Scythians, Greco-Bactria, etc. We looked at textiles, glass/ceramics, cave wall paintings, tomb figures, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The topic of this course was fascinating as it presented the Silk Roads as a network of cultural and artistic exchange instead of just economic. The course was also structured relatively loosely so as to prioritize lecture and student engagement over strenuous assignments (there were still assignments but they were not incredibly stressful, but still worthwhile and didactic).

One weakness of this course was that it perhaps had too much breadth. As someone who had never taken an art history course before, I found it a bit overwhelming and found myself wondering whether I had accidentally signed up for an advanced art history course. I wonder if the instructor could narrow the scope of the course a bit and focus more on introducing students to the discipline of art history and select regions of the Silk Roads.

Strengths: recorded lectures, interesting content
Weaknesses: lectures were a bit long for me since I have ADHD.
The class is very good overall.

Strengths: The course material is fascinating. We focused on a variety of objects and civilizations I had never even heard of before. 
Weaknesses: The readings were a bit dense at times. It was also difficult to map (temporally and spatially) the art / civilizations we looked at, in relation to one another.
Strengths: Mimi's passion and energy for the class! She was also incredibly understanding of the taxing semester, and was extremely willing to work with students to allow us to succeed.

I liked that in each lecture we explored some puzzling aspect of the art studied in that section. It was a bit difficult to track down all the different resources we needed for each class, especially since many of them had very large file sizes.

I really appreciated how much content was covered over the course of the semester, and how thorough the curriculum was in exposing us to a huge variety of cultures and forms of art. Only thing I might alter would be the density of the readings, which were often extensive for each class.

Strengths: Mimi's lectures are key strength of this course. She not only clearly knowledgeable about the many peoples, places, and things this course covers but also passionate about the things she teaches. The 30 minute section for this course was a very nice addition--it served as a great environment to sharpen observation and discussion skills. Another feature I loved about the course was the crosscurrents section. It was very cool to re-examine patterns we may or may not have missed throughout the many weeks of lectures in the final few classes! 
Also, I really appreciate that there is not too much stress about grades in this course. This freed me to be creative and to just focus on learning the things I enjoyed learning. As such, this course is one of a handful of courses where you can learn for the sake of learning, and as far as your motivation pushes you--and there's no shortage of materials to work with. 
Weaknesses: I think this course could have benefited from dedicating a portion of the live lecture to intentional student and teacher/TA discussion. I understand that this may not be ideal, as not everyone can log on to participate, but perhaps it could be made clear that these discussions are not mandatory but rather for our own enrichment. I realized from section that I learn a LOT from my classmates too--if there was just a bit more of what I experienced in section in lecture as well, that would be great!

All course materials, from lecture PowerPoints to readings, being available on Canvas was very helpful for review. Assignments are not heavy nor stressful. Called brief notes, they are a way to explore and engage with the material without having to do a lot of essay-writing and research. The final project is flexible so students can engage with the material in a way that is fun and interesting.
Professor Mimi really cares about her students' wellbeing. She is really passionate about the subject and good at explaining it in an organized way, so her lectures are engaging. Also, she is patient and open-minded towards students' questions and comments. For example, she allows creative flexibility for the final project (it is by default a 10-page paper but one can discuss with her to do something else). This semester, in light of the pandemic and other unfortunate events, she was very considerate of students' mental health, extending assignment deadlines and lightening the workload.
This course could improve by making it a bit clearer to students what resources are available. Perhaps tell students at the beginning of the course what is going to be posted on Canvas.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having both the live and recorded lectures was very helpful.

Live lectures were great and interactive with Q&A time at the end. Recorded lectures allowed me to succeed in this class. I'm sure the people who did the discussion sections really enjoyed it. I also liked that sections were not mandatory, but were offered to students who want to do a deeper dive.
The class is very good overall, it will be better if we have opportunities to see the artworks by going to museums, which would be possible if it's not an online course.
The option of attending lecture during the specified time or watching recorded lectures was helpful.
Recorded lecture
The slideshows and Zoom sections worked well, as well as the online submission of assignments.

Mimi is very accommodating and understanding of student's various situations. I appreciate that she did not force students to participate given the more difficult circumstances this year, and I also appreciate the plethora of different ways (live lecture, section, recorded lecture, powerpoint slides, readings, etc.) to engage with this course, and the flexibility students have in making use of these options or not. One major point is that the lack of timed assessments (i.e. tests) in this course made learning much more palatable and relaxed. 
I do still think some intentional live discussions could have been very enriching, although if this is implemented, this should not be a mandatory requirement. Section was a fantastic addition to the course and Emily Cox (TA) did an amazing job helping us study objects in finer detail, leading discussions with interesting questions and engaging students' questions with enthusiasm and curiosity.
Lecture recordings were helpful for catching up or reviewing. I hope that this can continue after the pandemic too.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Mimi is an incredible professor and the content of the course is very interesting. I will say that if you are new to art history it is a bit overwhelming. It is not a difficult class but the content is a lot to digest.

Yes, if you have an interest in Central Asia, China, Buddhism, Taoism, Christianity, other religions, and the Greco-Roman/Mediterranean world. Mimi is literally a treasure trove of knowledge regarding anything to do with the topic.

Yes--it is a fascinating subject, and Mimi is a great professor. This course will expose you to a lot of art that isn't usually highlighted in art history courses, although it should be. The workload is not heavy, which gives you the chance to really enjoy the material. The "brief notes" assignments are a great way to practice visual analysis, and the final project has so much room for creativity. It is an excellent survey class for art history majors, and it is also a must-take class for anyone interested in Eurasian art and history.
Definitely. It's a class that can broaden your vision of the world.

Yes! The class covers a niche topic that spans across continents and time. So few people know about the incredibly diverse array of goods exchanged along these trade routes, and the ancient civilizations that created them.
Yes, I would! I got the chance to learn about ancient Eurasian civilizations along the Silk Road, which I feel is otherwise an extremely underrated topic, despite how rich it is.
Yes! For students looking for a chill class and are interested in art history

I would recommend this course to those interested in the world of the Silk Roads or the cultures which were a part of it, and to anyone interested in examining the unique art of a variety of cultures that they might not have been exposed to otherwise (e.g., steppe art, Sogdian art, etc).

Yes. This course provides a low pressure environment to learn about something that maybe is right up your alley or completely new territory--my class had people in both categories. The assignments and projects facilitate and foster creativity and provide a considerable deal of maneuverability for students to be able to exercise their creative and artistic thinking.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Each lecture was live and virtual but also recorded for students whose schedules prevented them from attending live.
It was a live virtual lecture class the whole way through, but recorded lectures allowed me to catch up on my own time if I missed a session. I didn't attend the optional virtual discussion sections.
Mixture of recorded and live, as we were allowed to attend asynchronously.
We had to write discussion posts, and there were also optional virtual sections.
Virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
also recorded lecture and discussion section
Optional sections, which are also live zooms. Discussion posts, lecture PowerPoints, assignment instructions files, and lecture recordings on Canvas.

extras.title:
HSAR 144 01
        Arts of the Silk Road
